titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Went to Boston with Mary-Louisa—shaved at 222 Washington Street— Cadmus removed to Cambridge— Returned from 57. Mount Vernon Street to Quincy to dine. At 5 p.m took the Cars for Fall River— J. Q. Adams—Louisa Catherine Adams—Mary Catherine Adams—Mary Louisa Adams—Mrs Ellenor Goods, Margaret Delany—Isaac Hull Adams and WilliamWheeler, Coachman—8 persons. Lieutenant Joseph Harrod Adams goes with us as far a New-York. At 7 P.M we reached Fall river—shook hands with N Borden and embarked in the Steamer Bay State—

Tuesday 2. Novr. 1847. I went to bed and slept away the passage Fresh breeze through the night— Fog before daylight and until noon when we landed at New-York and took lodgings at the Astor House— Lieutenant Joseph Harrod Adams left us— We found at the Astor house Mrs Johnson of Utica and her brother Mr Masters— W. C. Johnson married last night to Miss Harriet Douw of Albany to arrive here next Friday—and to embark for England next Monday. Alexander C. Johnson called on us— Also John Jay and Mr Beakman with whom I attended a numerous meeting of the New-York historical Society at which Albert Gallatin presided and several papers were read— I got home at 10 p.m— The Ladies went to a Theatre to see French ballet dancers—

Wednesday 3. Novr. 1847.— Passed the day at New-York— Better chambers— Mrs De Wint with her daughter Isabella and Mr Furman—two children boy and girl of her daughter Louisa Mrs Whittemore called on us.— Arnold Buffum, and sundry other visitors here—day slip’d away I know not how— Could do nothing—suffering severely with the tooth ache— Otherwise gradually dying— I went with our Ladies to the opera— The Somnombula, Amina Madame Bishop—and the Mad Musician— Returned to our lodgings and in bed at 11. P.M.

Thursday 4 Novr 1847.— At 9 this morning we crossed the river to Jersey city and took the railway car for Philadelphia where we arrived at 2 P.M. and took our Lodgings at what was Jones’s Union Hotel—still called by his name, but he is no longer there— I walked immediately to the bank of North-America and received 150 dollars in gold for 5 coupons of 30 dollars each on Cincinnati bonds payable to Novr 1847— We dined and spent the Evening at Philadelphia

We left the House still called Jones’s hotel at Philadelphia though Jones is no longer there, and it is now kept as an appendage to the United States Hotel— We took at 8 O’Clock this morning the train of railroad Cars for Baltimore where we arrived at 2 O’Clock and found our friend Christopher Hughes as we alighted at the American house opposite the Railway depot— There we dined, and after dinner Mr Hughes called on us again with his daughter Margaret— I was tortured with the tooth ache and Margaret Dulany had been seized with violent cramps in the cars this morning— We took however the train of cars for Washington at 5 P.M and notwithstanding some obstacles and delays, reached our house in F Street about 8 O’Clock in the evening—all safe blessed be God!— J. Q. Adams Louisa Catherine Adams Mary Catherine Adams Mary Louisa Adams—Mrs Ellenor Goods, Margaret Dulany Isaac Hull Adams and WilliamWheeler Mrs Swift wife of Major Swift of the army had travell’d with us from Boston.
Call at Bank of the Metropolis and deposited 200 dollars in gold— Dr Gunnell extracted my tooth—which relieved my tongue
Mr Frye was here—
Sunday 7. Novr 1847. Sleep till morning— Relaxation from excessive stricture.
St. John’s Church 23. Sunday after Trinity.

Mr Pine preached—Philippians 3.17. and administered the communion—to the part of which after the Sermon I did not stay— After dinner he preached from John 10.14. “I know my sheep”—from which words Mr Pine drew an irresistible conclusion of the divinity of Jesus— Methinks a very different conclusion might be drawn from them— Mr Pine’s preaching always breeds in my mind an irresistible doubt whether he believes what he says Visits after church from Mrs Turnbull and her daughter Catherine— Mrs Swift Miss Abert daughter of Coll. Abert and Mr Moody—

Awoke in time to hear the clock strike 4— Slept again— Rose about 7.— Warm and fine weather— I am disabled even for prayer and can only ejaculate morning, noon, and eve one supplication of forgiveness and mercy from my God— And may I be found ready when the time shall come
At the Metropolis Bank—drew 100 dollars, and paid to Mrs J. Adams for household expenses—
At the Franklin Insurance Company Office received 475 dollars in Virginia bills— Dividend payable 1. Novr.
At the Bank of Washington—received 225 dollars in bills dividend on Washington city corporation 6 per cent stocks—dividends for 1. July and 1. Octr. 1847.
At the National Intelligencer Office and saw Joseph Gales Evening visits from Mr Larned— Mary E. E. Cutts and Mr Charles Gilpin of Philadelphia.

Tuesday 9. Novr. 1847— Summer weather— Slept till Clock struck 3.— Then awoke— Then slept again till day light— Hope of continued life from morn to morn, and no more— Prospect that every day will be my last— At Metropolis Bank— Deposited from Patriotic Bank Franklin Insurance Co. 475 dollars and from Washington Bank City Corporation stock 225— Visits from J Irwin Duncan nephew of Genl Irwin late whig candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania.—
Commodore Morris— Revd. Smith Pine— Judge W. Cranch Dr Thomas B. J. Frye here—
Card from C. S. Whitney—Door keeper H.R.U.S.
Received Documents of last Congress— 21 volumes—
Ride after dinner—till Sunset
Wednesday 10. Novr. 1847— A quiet night— Not entirely disabled from dressing myself—but very nearly.
Wrote with Mary Louisa—a weeks Diary from 1 to 7. Novr Morning walk— Visit morning to Mrs. Madison, and Miss Anna Payne—
Enos Ray with a Bill of 89 51 for keeping a pair of horses from 1. June to 1 Novr paid by check on Metropolis Bank.
1847. Thursday 11. Novr. Still a tolerable nights rest— Visit from Photius Kavasales.— Stationed at the Navy-Yard went to the Observatory, and found LieuttMaury there—and several others.
I saw the prime vertical
The refraction circle
The mural circle
The German circle
The equatorial
called at Commadore Morris’s house— Not at home. Visits from Mr Ogle Tayloe and Miss Virginia Tayloe. Cards from Dr Ringgold and Mr Clingman.
Dr John M Thomas was here this Evening—very unwell. He will come again to-morrow morning—
Mary-Louisa spent the day at Mrs Swifts’.
Friday 12 Novr 1847— A quiet Night— Unable entirely to dress myself— My right hand disabled for writing—read the 110th Psalm—

Morning visits from Coll. Hayne and Asbury Dickins.— Walk to the city-hall— Met Asbury Dickens again— Disabled hand— Dr John M Thomas, long consultation with him. Received a Letter from Aaron Leggett with a printed memorial from him to Congress upon his claims on Mexico— Morning visit from Stephen Douglas now a Senator from the State of Illinois— After dinner ride.
Dr Thomas was here this evening with his father

Saturday 13. Novr. 1847. Unquiet and half sleepless night Proof that I am to expect no permanent improvement or relief— Morning visit from Dr Todsen—recd. Littell’s living Age—N. 183— Letter from Mrs C. F. Adams, and Bill of lading for a box of merchandize, by schooner Harriet from Boston.

. . . to the general Post Office— Cave Johnson the Post-master general not there—at the Presidents in Cabinet Meeting— Saw the Second Assistant Postmaster General W. B. Brown—left with him A Tillinghasts letter—walk home— Met Arthur Stansbury, who walked home with me but did not come in— Afternoon ride speculation in the employment of my lost hours.
A perturbed Night and desolate morning.
Instruments at the Washington observatory

list.item: 1. A 14 foot Equatorial quick aperture Plate 11.
2. A seven foot Transit instrument 53 inches aperture Plate 3.
3. A Mural Circle—five foot with a Telescope of the same focal length and 4 inches clear aperture. Plates 5 and 7.
4. A Meridian Circle 30 inch with a five foot Telescope and 4 inches aperture Plates 5. 7. and 8
5. A Prime Vertical Transit Instrument 6 feet 6 inches of focal length and 48 in clear aperture Plate 4

6. A Comet Seeker 2 foot 10 inches with a 4 1/4 inches object glass-Plated astronomical observations published by authority of the Secretary of the Navy— Washington Vol 1.
Appendix page 2—
7. A refraction circle with a Telescope 8 feet long and 6.6 inch object glass with two 48 inch circles each having 6 reading microscopes— Plates 9 and 10 p. 17.

div.p: 1847. Sunday 14. Novr. 24th. Sunday after Trinity—

Heard Mr Pine A.M from 2 Corinthians 7.10. [“]For godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of, but the sorrow of the world worketh death.” and P.M. from John 8.11. [“]Neither do I condemn thee: go and sin no more”
Monday 15. Novr.— A night of interrupted repose preceding an almost idle day.

Brother Paul and brother Bernard monks of the order of St. Francis from the County of Galway Ireland with certificates from W. Mathews Rector of St. Patricks Church and James B. Donelan Rector of St. Mathews Church making collections for the relief of the distressed in Ireland. 5.
Call at the Navy Department to see the Secretary John Y Mason, but he was just gone over to the Presidents.
Dr John M. Thomas here— Medical advice.
Observations on the Aboriginal Monuments of the Missisippi valley—by E. G. Squier—

Settled account with Isaac Hull Adams for expenses of Journey from Quincy to Washington—1–5 Novr 1847— amount of the expense 142:30. check to I. H. A—57:30. Evening visit from my neighbour Albion K Parris second Comptroller of the Treasury.— Mrs John Adams spent the day and evening at her aunt Mrs Frye’s.
Tuesday 16 Novr 1847. A half sleepless—yet merciful Night Malade Imaginaise process

Mrs Armsburg— Her first husband’s name was Hussey. Enquires for her son—enlisted as a boy in the navy at 13. Three years ago discharged as incompetent for service. I advised her to apply at the Navy Department for information I called at the Navy Department but the Secretary was in cabinet meeting at the Presidents— Met Lewis C Levin—member from Philadelphia— Call at Colman’s hotel and left a card for Stephen Douglas Senator from Illinois— Met Lieutt. M. F. Maury and promised to call at the Observatory this Evening if the Sky is bright— Visit from W. W. Seaton— Mayor of the city.
1847— Tuesday 16 Novr 1847—
Officers attached to the Observatory in 1846.

At 6 P.M. I went to the Observatory, and with Lieutt. M. F. Maury inspected the Moon, being its 9th. day— I can give no description of its appearance, which soon became beclouded and indistinct— I returned home before 8 O Clock. Mary Louisa spent the Evening at Miss Juliana Randall’s
W. M. Thomas with papers—a boatswain and prize master I told him he must state his claim in writing and I would present it for him to the Secretary of the Navy

I called at the Navy Department, but the Secretary was in cabinet meeting at the Presidents— I rode to the Capitol, and took out of the Congress library Pliny’s Letters with the Panegyric of Trajan— The Panegyric is not included with Melmoth’s Translation of the Letters, and there is no English translation of the Panegyric— The one I took out in French by DeSacy Berlin 1758.— I took out also the second volume of the English translation of Plato by Floyer Sydenham and Thomas Taylor in 5 volumes 4to I took the second for the Timaeus.— Met George Marsh member from Vermont— The Dial and dogdays— Conversations lexicon.
1847. Wednesday 17. Novr. 1847.— Minutes of my last days— Awake between 3 and 4 A.M.
Letter from Arnold Buffum New-York 15. Novr 1847—with clips from newspapers urging a world’s convention to be held at New-York on the first Monday of June 1848.

1847. Thursday 18 Novr. 1847. Call at the Navy Department and saw the Secretary John Y. Mason— Left with him the papers of W. M. Thomas— I mentioned to him my earnest desire for an appropriation for the composition and annual publication of a nautical almanac—Mem?— To reflect further upon the composition of nautical almanac— I intended to have visited the observatory again this evening, but the sky clouded up and I postponed my observations
Friday 19— Novr 1847— Rainy Night—

I called at the Navy Department and left with the Secretary the charge of W. M. Thomas—against the Government for 2 Months service 50 dollars which I had yesterday inadvertently left on my table when I took his other papers to the Department.

An orphan boy 13 or 14 years of age came with certificates of recommendation from James B. Donelan the rector of St Matthews Catholic Church—and N. Callan—to procure for the boy whom they name Joseph J. Head employment— What he himself wants is to be appointed a page in the House of Representatives— He says his name is Joseph Hill— That his father was a baptist minister who has been these five years dead and his mother died long before him— That his present employment is to carry round the Baltimore Clipper for distributing which he pays the publishers weekly and that he pays two dollars a week for his board— I told him I would help him to get him the appointment of a page if I could, and bade him come to me again next Wednesday.
General Thomas S. Jesup, with two of his daughters Lucy Ann and Jane and Jane paid us an evening visit

Saturday 20 Novr 1847. My hand more and more disabled— W. M. Thomas was here, but the Secretary of the Navy has not yet decided on his claims, for arrears of pay, and for an appointment as boatswain in the navy— He is impatient to go to his family at Baltimore— I rode to the Capitol and walked home met at the Post Office of H.R.U.S. Robert Barnwell Rhett of South Carolina who was courteous and civil. A Penknife
B. B. French gone to the Penitentiary— Dial of H.R.U S. My Sonnet which was framed and hung up there was taken away last winter—

Walking home I met Arthur Stansbury the Reporter, and John W. Davis of Indiana— Speaker of H.R.U.S. at the last or 29th. Congress— Not a member of the 30th. Congress— He told me lodged where he always had at Mr Leonard Harbaughs in 8th Street— After dinner ride with my wife and Mary. At the Observatory— Viewed through the equatorial, with Lieutt Maury and profesor Hubbard the full moon—the Planets Neptune—Iris Mars and Saturn with his ring and one Satellite Viewed also through the West transit instrument the transit of two stars— Lieutt. Maury told me he was writing me a long Letter— I came home about 8 O Clock— Visit from Charles B. King the Painter.
Sunday 21. Novr 1847.— Eruption round my right knee

Went with Isaac Hull Adams to the Unitarian church where Mr Allen preached from Matthew 24.10. an excellent sermon—we walked home— Dr. Thomas was here— Notice was given of thanksgiving day next Thursday and a collection— After dinner at St. John’s church 25th Sunday after Trinity—and Mr Pine preached from Revelation 3.18. I counsel thee to buy of me gold tried in the fire that thou mayest be rich— It was a monitory discourse at the close of the ecclesiastical year, and the approaching commencement of a new one— Evening unpromising.

Monday 22 Novr 1847— Heard the Clock strike 4 A.M. Thomas Duckett a negro soliciting contributions to purchase his freedom and that of his family— Also for another family. B. B. French— Heard I had enquired for him at the House on Saturday and is going to Baltimore this day on business I recommended Joseph Hill for appointment as one of the pages of the House— He said the pages were appointed by the door keeper—but he would lay the name of Joseph Hill laid before the present doorkeeper to give him a chance of appointment— He said he had been falsely charged with turning out the only whig subclerk left in the office by Macnulty— The direct reverse was the truth— He said Mr Marsh had promised to vote for him unless the party caucus screws should be too closely applied to him— I said I should heed no party Graces

1847. Monday 22. Novr 1847. A man by the name of J. H G McCutchen came to enquire if I would purchase the negro and his family who had applied to me. I declined. M’Cutchen I take it for granted is a slave dealer

Tuesday 23. Novr. 1847— A succession of visitors—among the visitors from Virginia named Cleghton & Robinson— Cleghton came to solicit my vote for his father as keeper of the post office of HRUS— Also two Quakers or Friends one named David Adams from Madison County New-York—the other Lewis from Pennsylvania— David Adams was very inquisitive of genealogy—and spoke of 4 generations of his own ending in Connecticut and New-York but not of the Henry Adams brood. Mary Louisa, went as a bride maid to the wedding of Juliana Randall to a man from Philadelphia named Elliot— Isaac Hull Adams spent the evening abroad— Mrs. Goods was called away to two of her married daughters Mrs Mitchell and Mrs Hodson—the last was prematurely delivered of twins still born

Mrs Goods came home this morning— Warm rain, night and morn— Recd yesterday an invitation from Messr Willard to the opening dinner of the City Hotel this day at 4 pm which I decline— An invitation from S Draper junr. Charles A Peabody, John Thomas, B W. Binney and L. B Wynnard Committee of the New-England Society of the City of New-York to the dinner at the Astor House on the 22d. of Decr next. A Letter from E. C. Wines of Burlington New Jersey, about Normal school for the State— And my opinion is asked on this subject— I decline the invitations to dinner— A letter from G. Washington Georgetown 22 Novr 1847 declaring himself a Candidate for the appointment of Serjeant at arms of HR.U.S. and an invitation from Coll. J. J. Abert for Saturday evening 7. Oclock— I called at Colman’s Hotel to see Mrs. George Parkman and her son and daughter, but they had left the city
in the Steamer for Richmond, Virginia—the day before yesterday— Mary Louisa dined with a bridal party at Mr Thomas Munroe’s.

At the Unitarian church Mr Allen preached a sermon of thanksgiving for the enjoyment of blessings National and individual, but he touched upon no political topic, and he delivered his text in so low a tone of voice that I did not hear whence it was taken—but its reference was to the land flowing with milk and honey— We had visits from Coll Arthur P and Mrs Hayne— Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa spen the Evening at Mrs Randalls

Friday 26 Novr 1847. Thanks to God for existence yet prolonged with faculties of body and mind dilapidated, and approaching the last stage of decay—and never to be restored upon earth— The hope alone is left of another and improved state of existence.—

Walk round by 4 1/2 Street— Met Clingman of North Carolina alsoSargent of Philadelphia— H. Secretario— I had received a Letter from him soliciting my vote for him as clerk of the house. I told him I should be glad to vote for him but my vote was pledged— He thought circumstances might occur to modify my intentions— He walked with me to my door but did not come in— After dinner ride with my wife

Saturday 27 Novr 1847— Uncomfortable Night awake before the Clock struck 3. and no sleep afterwards— Morning remedy.— Visits from John West and P. C. Claughton of Alexandria Virginia and also from Matthew St Clair Clark who said he would not be a candidate against Mr Johnson as Postmaster for the House, but against Mr M’Cormick which I did not understand— A young woman named Miss Stafford was here with a pension claim for her grandmother, and another for a Mrs Ashemore— Among her documentary vouchers was a Letter from J. G. Palfrey, as Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts dated 6. March 1847.

I told Miss Stafford that Mr Palfrey was a member elect of the 30th. congress and that she would do well to apply to him for assistance in support of her claims, if as I hoped he should be here at the opening of the Session, which I was sorry to say was very doubtful, as I am informed he was a few days since very ill—
Morning walk round 4 1/2 street— Evening party of men at Coll. J. J. Abert’s— I went at half past 7. and came home about 9—before supper. Mary Louisa spent the evening at Mrs Randalls

At the Unitarian Church A.M. Mr Allen preached from John 3.11. [“]Verily verily I say unto thee, We speak what we do know, and testify that we have seen”— At St John’s Church it was Advent Sunday— My wife went and took the Communion— There was no Sermon after dinner there but catechising of Children— In the evening at 7 I went again to the Unitarian church where Mr Allen preached from Matthew 6–25. Therefore I say unto you take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on, is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment? we came home about 9 O’Clock— A cold night.
A Nightmare with the morning sleep—

Ride to the Office of Stephen Pleasonton 5th Auditor with letter from William B. Duggan of Quincy in behalf of Captain Charles Swift for the appointment of keeper of the light-house on Minot’s ledge— Cohassett Rocks— The recommendations had been sent to the Secy of the Treasury the 23d. of Octr— Mr Pleasonton referred me to Mr M’Ginnis at the Treasury Department— The Secretary was at the Presidents— Mr M’Ginnis said the Recommendations would be laid before him for his decision.

Ride to the Capitol— Where I compared my Chronometer with the Dial of H.R.U.S.—and lost my glove— In the evening we had a visit from Mr John A. Rockwell a member elect of H.R.U.S. who arrived this day. Louisa went to the Railway Depot expecting the arrival of her friend Louisa Agnel with Mr Robert Schenk a member H.R.U.S. from Ohio—but they did not come.
A night of interrupted repose—and a day of a crippled hand as all the remnant of my days must be—

Visitors whose names my Memory will not retain and among them Mr Howard a publican of this city with a man by the name of John Mitchel, with both arms amputated, blown up in firing a feu de joy, in the summer of 1846 for the victories of Palo and Resaca La Palma—
I rode to the Capitol and enquired at the Clerks office of HRUS. for my lost glove which was not there and I did not find— I received a printed recommendation signed by W. W. Seaton and others
